newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish parties plan censure of government.
newsitem.headline: Turkish parties plan censure of government.

text.p: Turkey's main leftist parties said on Tuesday they would file censure motions against the country's Islamist-led government to protect the secular democratic system.
The fresh political tension and a higher-than-expected inflation figure for January sparked a sharp decline on the recently buoyant stock market.

"We decided it was necessary to start the legal process to free the country from this government," Bulent Ecevit, leader of the Democratic Left Party, told his MPs. He said the motion would focus on problems of the "secular, democratic republic, foreign affairs, economic and social issues and security."

Turkey's secularists have been enraged by an anti-Israel rally in an Ankara district held by the ruling Islamist Welfare Party last week. In an apparent show of strength by the secular army, a convoy of tanks and military vehicles paraded through the area on Tuesday.
Ecevit said Welfare was the target of the censure motion, adding it would be supported by many members of the junior coalition partner, the conservative True Path Party (DYP).

Sukru Gurel, a senior MP from Ecevit's party, said the motion would be presented to parliament at the latest by Thursday. The coalition holds a narrow majority but the motion would need the support of both leftist parties, DYP's rival the Motherland Party and some other MPs, to pass.
"The situation is so urgent, the danger befalling the democratic, secular state is so big, that we must act immediately," Gurel told Reuters.

Deputies from the other major leftist party, the Republican People's Party, said in a statement they planned to present their own censure motion to the speaker of parliament on Wednesday, state-run Anatolian news agency reported.
Necmettin Erbakan, Turkey's first Islamist prime minister, apparently renounced his radical pro-Islam and anti-Western election pledges after forming the governing coalition last June.
But he has angered members of Deputy Prime Minister Tansu Ciller's DYP and the powerful army in recent weeks with plans to build mosques and other Islamist programmes.
Analysts say the possibility of early polls has forced Welfare to woo the religious and protest votes that gave the party a narrow plurality in general polls in December 1995.
The coalition has been strained recently by Erbakan's pro-Islam proposals.
Erbakan's confidence in pushing the Welfare line has also been boosted by favourable economic news. The stock market has risen over 50 percent this year on hopes for the economy.
But shares fell seven percent on Tuesday after inflation data showing the economy was still far from stable and on concerns about an apparent deterioration in the political outlook.

The European Union added to those concerns with a warning from Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van Mierlo that Europe faced difficulties in fully embracing Turkey, ranging from Ankara's human rights record to the country's Moslem identity.
Ankara has sought full EU membership since 1987 as a central part of its efforts to cement links with the West.

Highlighting secularist sensitivity over Islamist activity, the Interior Ministry has suspended the Islamist mayor of Ankara's Sincan district, Bekir Yildiz, over a "Jerusalem Night" protest, according to state-run Anatolian news agency.
A state security court also investigating the event ordered the detention of Welfare's Yildiz, Anatolian said.
Comments by Yildiz at the rally were criticised in the media as a call to implement the strict Islamic sharia law.
Military officials denied the action was a response to the rally. "This has nothing to do with that. This is training that we do all the time," an official said.
